wikipedia_page.main: Frederick Spurrell (2 August 1824 – 23 February 1902) was an Anglican priest and archaeologist.

response: *Frederick Spurrell (1824–1902), Rev. English; English archaeology (Essex and Sussex)
*Rev. Frederick Spurrell (1824–1902), Chaplain in Stockholm (1849), and Rector of Faulkbourne, Essex (1853–1898)

Gray died in 1826 and was buried under the floor of the nave of All Saints Church, West Ham.Fry K., History of the Parishes of East and West Ham (1888) His widow Lydia (1794-1855) continued to manage the business with the Dacre family. Lydia was the youngest daughter of the coppersmith James Shears. John and Lydia's children included Ann Thomson Gray, author of The Twin Pupils: Or, An Education at Home, and Frances Gray, who married her cousin the Rev. Frederick Spurrell. They were also related, through marriage, to the Watney family of brewers.Spurrell, J. C., The life of Charles Spurrell and his family's links to the Watney and Gray brewing families, Brewery History No. 138 (December 2010)

Born at Mile End in Stepney, London, Spurrell was the eldest son of Dr. Flaxman and Ann Spurrell and a descendant of the Spurrell family of Norfolk. He was a nephew of the Rev. Frederick Spurrell, a fellow archaeologist, and an uncle of the biologist and author Herbert George Flaxman Spurrell.
Augustus Shears was a cousin of Rev. Ernest Henry Shears and Rev. Frederick Spurrell.
He was a cousin of Rev. Augustus Shears and Rev. Frederick Spurrell.
* Reverend Frederick Spurrell, M.A., A.K.C. (1824–1902), grandson

response: The church is dedicated to Saint Germanus, a bishop of Auxerre in Late Antique Gaul, who visited Britain to suppress the Pelagian heresy in about 429. The church may have been dedicated to Saint Germanus because it was consecrated on his feast day, 31 July.Rev. Frederick Spurrell, Faulkbourn Church, Essex Archaeological Society Transperiodical (1878).

response: As the intended appointee, the Rev. George Williams, could not be released from his duties at King’s College, Cambridge, the Rev. Frederick Spurrell was sent instead, arriving in Stockholm as the first regularly appointed chaplain in April 1849.J. C. Spurrell, Frederick Spurrell’s letter from Stockholm, 1849 (The Anglo-Swedish Society newsletter, 2015).
